xxl.io
Class BlockBasedQueue

java.lang.Object
  |
  +--xxl.collections.AbstractQueue
        |
        +--xxl.io.StreamQueue
              |
              +--xxl.io.BlockBasedQueue
public class BlockBasedQueue
extends StreamQueue
implements Convertable, FIFOQueue

This class provides a queue that uses a container for storing blocks of serialized data. Neither the peek method nor the remove method are implemented by the block based queue. A converter is used for serializing and de-serializing the elements of the queue.

The block based queue serializes its elements and stores block of this serialized data in a container. In order to keep the order of this block, the id of the next block is stored at the end of each block.

Example usage (1). 

     // create a new block based queue with ...

     BlockBasedQueue queue = new BlockBasedQueue(

         // a map container for storing the serialized elements

         new MapContainer(),

         // a block size of 20 bytes

         20,

         // an integer converter

         IntegerConverter.DEFAULT_INSTANCE,

         // an input buffer of 0 bytes

         new Constant(0),

         // an output buffer of 4 bytes (size of a serialized integer)

         new Constant(4)
     );

     // create an iteration over 20 random Integers (between 0 and 100)

     Iterator iterator = new Enumerator(20);

     // insert all elements of the given iterator

     queue.insertAll(iterator);

     // print all elements of the queue

     while (queue.hasNext())
         System.out.println(queue.next());

     // close the open queue after use

     queue.close();

See Also:
Constant, Container, DataInput, DataOutput, FIFOQueue, Function, InputStream, IOException, OutputStream, WrappingRuntimeException

Field Detail

FACTORY_METHOD

public static final Function FACTORY_METHOD
A factory method to create a new BlockBasedQueue (see contract for FACTORY_METHOD in interface Queue). In contradiction to the contract in Queue it may only be invoked with an array (parameter list) (for further details see Function) of objects. The array (parameter list) will be used for initializing the random access file queue by calling the constructor BlockBasedQueue((Container) array[0], 256, (Function) array[1], new Constant(0), new Constant(0)).
See Also:
Function

container

protected Container container
The container is internally used for storing the blocks that contains the serialized elements of the queue.

blockSize

protected int blockSize
The size of a block stored in the container. Every block stored in the container contains blockSize bytes of serialized data.

bytes

protected int bytes
The number of bytes stored by blocks in the container.

readBlockId

protected Object readBlockId
The id of readBlock, i.e. the block the queue actually reads from.

readBlockOffset

protected int readBlockOffset
The offset of readBlock, i.e. the block the queue actually reads from.

writeBlockId

protected Object writeBlockId
The id of writeBlock, i.e. the block the queue actually writes to.

writeBlockOffset

protected int writeBlockOffset
The offset of writeBlock, i.e. the block the queue actually writes to.

readBlock

protected Block readBlock
The block the queue actually reads from.

writeBlock

protected Block writeBlock
The block the queue actually writes to.

dummyBlock

protected Block dummyBlock
A dummy block that is used for getting a new id when a new write block is created. When creating a new write block, the dummy block is inserted into the container in order to get a valid id for the write block. When the creation of the write block is finished, the the dummy block is updated by the write block.

inputStream

protected InputStream inputStream
The input stream is used for reading the serialized elements of the queue. It is set to an input stream, that reads the next bytes from the actual read block. When the actual read block is totally read out, it is removed from the container and the next block to read out is taken from it. The next block is determined by the block id stored at the end of the exhausted block. The input stream implicitly adjusts the number of bytes contained by the queue.

outputStream

protected OutputStream outputStream
The output stream is used for writing serialized elements to the queue. It is set to an output stream, that writes given bytes to the actual write block. When the actual write block is full, a new block is inserted into the container. In order to be able to determine the next block, when reading the serialized data, the id of the new block is stored at the end of the old write block. The output stream implicitly adjusts the number of bytes contained by the queue.
Constructor Detail

BlockBasedQueue

public BlockBasedQueue(Container container,
                       int blockSize,
                       Converter converter,
                       Function newObject,
                       Function inputBufferSize,
                       Function outputBufferSize,
                       int size,
                       int bytes,
                       Object readBlockId,
                       int readBlockOffset,
                       Object writeBlockId,
                       int writeBlockOffset)
Constructs a new block based queue containing the elements that are stored in blocks of the specified size in the given container. The specified converter is used for serializing and de-serializing the elements of the queue and the given factory method is used for initializing the elements of the queue before the blocks are read out. The specified functions determine the size of the input buffer and the output buffer. The given int value size and bytes determines what is the initial size of the queue and how many bytes are needed for serializing its elements. readBlockId, readBlockOffset, writeBlockId and writeBlockOffset specifies the id and the offset of the actual read and write block.
Parameters:
container - the container that is used for storing the blocks of serialized data. The serialized objects contained by this container can be used as initial elements of the queue.
blockSize - the size of a block that is used for storing the serialized elements of the queue.
converter - the converter that is used for serializing and de-serializing the elements of the queue.
newObject - a factory method that is invoked in order to initialize the elements of the queue, before a block is read out.
inputBufferSize - a function that determines the size of the input buffer.
outputBufferSize - a function that determines the size of the output buffer.
size - the initial size of the queue.
bytes - the number of bytes needed for storing the initial elements of the queue.
readBlockId - the id of the actual block to read from.
readBlockOffset - the offset of the actual block to read from.
writeBlockId - the id of the actual block to write to.
writeBlockOffset - the offset of the actual block to write to.

Constructs a new block based queue containing the elements that are stored in blocks of the specified size in the given container. The specified converter is used for serializing and de-serializing the elements of the queue. The specified functions determine the size of the input buffer and the output buffer. The given int value size and bytes determines what is the initial size of the queue and how many bytes are needed for serializing its elements. readBlockId, readBlockOffset, writeBlockId and writeBlockOffset specifies the id and the offset of the actual read and write block.
This constructor is equivalent to the call of BlockBasedQueue(container, blockSize, converter, new Constant(null), inputBufferSize, outputBufferSize, size, bytes, readBlockId, readBlockOffset, writeBlockId, writeBlockOffset)

writeBlockOffset - the offset of the actual block to write to.

The specified functions determine the size of the input buffer and the output buffer. Constructs a new block based queue containing the elements that are stored in blocks of the specified size in the given container (see methods read and write for further detail). The specified functions determine the size of the input buffer and the output buffer.

Method Detail

read

public void read(DataInput dataInput)
          throws IOException
Reads the state of this block based queue from a data input. This method can be used for initializing the queue with the elements that are stored in blocks of bytes in the container without using the corresponding constructor (you know, this one with twelve parameters).
This implementation reads the fields size, bytes, readBlockId, readBlockOffset, writeBlockId and writeBlockOffset from the given data input.
Specified by:
read in interface Convertable
Parameters:
the - data input to read from the state of this queue.

write

public void write(DataOutput dataOutput)
           throws IOException
Writes the actual state of this block based queue to a data output. This method can be used for serializing the actual state of the queue in order to used it again in another session without calling the corresponding constructor (you know, this one with twelve parameters).
This implementation writes the fields size, bytes, readBlockId, readBlockOffset, writeBlockId and writeBlockOffset to the given data output.
Specified by:
write in interface Convertable
Parameters:
the - data output to write to the state of this queue.

removeBlock

protected void removeBlock()
                    throws IOException
Removes the actual block to read from out of the container and sets readBlockId to the id of the next block to read from. The id of the next block is stored at the end of the removed block.

inputStream

protected InputStream inputStream()
Opens an input stream for reading the serialized elements of the queue and returns it.
This implementation simply returns inputStream.
Overrides:
inputStream in class StreamQueue
Returns:
an input stream for reading the serialized elements of the queue.

outputStream

protected OutputStream outputStream()
Opens an output stream for writing serialized elements to the queue and returns it.
This implementation simply returns outputStream.
Overrides:
outputStream in class StreamQueue
Returns:
an output stream for writing serialized elements to the queue.

clear

public void clear()
Removes all of the elements from this queue. The queue will be empty after this call returns so that size() == 0.
This implementation removes all blocks from the container and sets size and bytes to 0. Thereafter the actual blocks are set to null.
Overrides:
clear in class StreamQueue

close

public void close()
Closes this queue and releases any system resources associated with it. This operation is idempotent, i.e., multiple calls of this method takes the same effect as a single call.
This implementation secures that the actual state of the block to write to is stored in the container and sets the actual blocks to null.
Overrides:
close in class StreamQueue

main

public static void main(String[] args)
The main method contains some examples how to use a BlockBasedQueue. It can also be used to test the functionality of a BlockBasedQueue.
Parameters:
args - array of String arguments. It can be used to submit parameters when the main method is called.
